title: Late Succession Habitat
text:
There is increased interest in old growth and mature forests in the United States due to the Biden Administration’s Executive Order on ‘Strengthening the Nation’s Forests, Communities, and Local Economies’. Which ordered the Department of Agriculture and the Department of the Interior to “define, identify, and complete an inventory of old-growth and mature forests on Federal lands and shall make such inventory publicly available”. Non-profit organizations and local governments in particular have taken an interest in old growth and mature forests in the Central Upper Peninsula.
Here we explore ‘late-succession’ habitat as defined by LANDFIRE in the Biophysical Settings models and descriptions which is specifically defined for each BpS (historical ecosystem). In LANDFIRE, late-succession was not specifically designed for old-growth/mature forest identification. We use LANDFIRE data here because:

There are robust descriptions and ecological models for each ecosystem that have been peer reviewed. Learn more about the process from Blankenship et al., (2021), and Swaty et al., (2021).
The datasets and models cover all lands, not just agency lands for example.
Late succession as defined in the LANDFIRE models and descriptions is ‘highly-inclusive’, and can serve to highlight areas for more detailed field examinations.
LANDFIRE’s view of ecosystems includes natural disturbances (including Indigenous burning, wildfires, windthrow, etc.), which is in line with current ecological theory. This is particularly important in disturbance-driven ecosystems such as the Northern Pine(-Oak) Forests which would have had frequent surface fires prior to European Settlement. These fires resulted in a fair amount of ’Late-Open” successional habitat.

INSERT SUMMARY HERE…DIFFERENT DATA DIFFERENT RESULTS, THOUGH CONVERGENCE ON ‘MATURE’, HARD TO DEFINE

title: Late Succession Habitat
text:
Other datasets
Above we explored “late-succession” habitat, which might be considered to be the ‘top of the funnel’ or widest possible way to look at later stages of ecosystem development. Below we explore some other related datasets currently available.

Mature and Old Growth Data from the US Forest Service (USFS)
To support “Executive Order 14072 (also known as “Strengthening the Nation’s Forests, Communities, and Local Economies”)“, USFS scientists have defined and mapped ‘mature’ and ‘old-growth’ forests on USFS and Bureau of Land Management lands of the US. Their definitions are largely based on relatively reliably mapped characteristics of tree diameter and trees per acre.
We strongly recommend reading the full report, available here, and exploring the data viewer.
At time of this assessment, raw data was not available for further assessment to our knowledge.






Screenshot of the USFS Mature and Old-Growth Forest Map.





For the Central Upper Peninsula area, a few things stand out from their map:

There are no ‘High Old-Growth’ areas.
High ‘Mature/Low Old-Growth’ areas are mapped in the eastern portion of the assessment area, largely in line with Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore, and the western area of the Hiawatha National Forest.



Mature and Old-Growth mapping effort by Barnett et al. (2023)
In a recently published paper, Barnett et al. (2023) classified, inventoried and mapped mature and old-growth (MOG) forests for the US. Whereas many MOG mapping attempts use some combination of tree height and/or age and/or density, the authors assessed carbon accumulation, and assumed (briefly) that old-growth occurred:

“…at the age when the density of total forest carbon stored in live and dead biomass reaches 95% of the empirically derived maximum, and the mature forest stage as occurring between the peak average carbon increment and the age of onset of old growth.”

At time of this assessment, raw data was not available for further assessment to our knowledge. However from Figure 8 in the paper a few patterns jump out:

Most of the Upper Peninsula is mapped as ‘young’ or ‘mature’.

There appear to be scattered pixels (small areas) with ‘Old-Growth’ scattered around the area, with no discernible concentrations of old-growth.



Mature and Old-Growth Contributions project by DellaSala et al. (2022)
Authors of this paper used combinations of forest canopy height, cover and above-ground living biomass to map mature and old-growth forests (among many other things). To summarize, the authors held workshops with scientists to develop ‘rulesets’ or thresholds of the three aforementioned parameters for each of 28 forest types groups, then combined the necessary datasets to map mature and old-growth forests.
The authors do share their datasets at https://www.matureforests.org/data. Here’s a quick map of ‘mature’ forest pixels for the analysis area.






Map of mature areas as mapped by Della-Sala et al. (2022).





This map most closely aligns with ours, identifying a substantial amount of the analysis area as ‘mature’.

Mapping wildfire exposure risk involves the integration of diverse data sources and advanced analytical techniques to identify and assess areas susceptible to wildfire incidents. Leveraging satellite imagery, climate data, vegetation types, and historical fire patterns, the mapping process aims to quantify the level of risk in different regions. Machine learning models can play a crucial role in predicting the likelihood of wildfire occurrence, considering factors such as weather conditions, topography, and human activities. The resulting risk maps provide valuable insights for proactive wildfire management strategies, enabling authorities and communities to allocate resources effectively, implement preventative measures, and plan evacuation routes to mitigate the impact of potential wildfires. This comprehensive approach not only aids in understanding the spatial distribution of wildfire exposure risk but also facilitates informed decision-making to enhance overall wildfire resilience.

Historical Fire Regimes





Historical Fire Return Intervals for assessment area.




PLACEHOLDER TEXT FROM CHAT GPT
Pre-European Settlement Era:
Native American communities in the Upper Peninsula (UP) likely influenced fire regimes through intentional burning for various purposes, such as promoting vegetation for hunting and agriculture. 1800s Logging Era:
Extensive logging activities in the 19th century altered the landscape, with increased slash and debris providing fuel for fires. Logging practices may have influenced fire frequency and intensity. Early 20th Century Fire Suppression:
Fire suppression efforts became prevalent in the early 20th century, impacting the natural fire regime. This led to the accumulation of fuels, potentially increasing the risk of intense wildfires. Mid-20th Century Policy Shift:
Policies promoting fire suppression began to change in the mid-20th century, recognizing the ecological role of fire. Prescribed burns were occasionally used to mimic natural fire regimes and restore ecosystems. Late 20th Century:
Increased understanding of fire ecology led to a more nuanced approach, combining fire suppression with controlled burns to manage vegetation and reduce the risk of uncontrolled wildfires.

title: Current Vegetation
text:
Patterns on the current landscape

Almost all of the area is naturally vegetated, with ~ 5% classified as ‘Agricultural’ and ~2% classified as ‘Developed’.

Just over 1/4 of the CUP is classified as Northern Hardwoods Forest, and 1/4 as Alkaline Conifer-Hardwood Swamp.
In total, ~37% is typed in various ‘riparian’ ecosystems.

To learn more about the dataset, go to https://landfire.gov/evt.php. To explore descriptions of these types, vist the Terrestrial Ecological Systems documentaton by NatureServe.






Dominant ecosystems ~2022, chart created with Existing Vegetation Type data from https://landfire.gov/evt.php.

title: Current Vegetation
text:
Historical ecosystems





Dominant ecosystems just prior to European colonization, map created with Biophysical Settings data from https://landfire.gov/bps.php.





For context (not necessarily direct comparison as datasets generated using different methods), we mapped the dominant ecosystems that would have been in the CUP just prior to European Settlement. A few notable patterns include:

There have not been substantial changes in general, i.e., the area was dominated by riparian and northern hardwood types.
The ‘Aspen-Birch’ type that is mapped on the current landscape may have also occurred historically, but may have been a ‘developmental stage’ within an ecosystem. LANDFIRE data does not allow for direct exploration of this type.
While both ‘current’ and ‘historical’ vegetation maps were created with LANDFIRE data, there are differences in naming conventions due to evolving science and the datasets were created using very different approaches (e.g, existing vegetation mapped with satellite data, historical vegetation was modeled). Because of those differences only general trends can be assessed.

As noted above historical information presented for context. It does not necessarily equal a ‘Desired Future Condition’.
To learn about the dataset, visit https://landfire.gov/bps.php , and to explore specific types, including descriptions, go to https://landfirereview.org/search.php.

title: Current Vegetation
text:
General comparisons-another way to explore
As noted above, making comparisons between the ‘current’ and ‘historical’ ecosystem datasets can be problematic. One way to ameliorate some of the data comparison challenges is to ‘group’ types and look at general patterns. For example we can group then compare all ‘riparian’ types to explore trends. It is important to interpret changes as being changes in what was mapped, which may or may not be actuality.
In the chord diagram below, you can hover over an outer band (e.g., near the phrase ’ Past Hardwood’ on the right) to see how much of an historical area is still mapped as that type, and how much is different. For example, of what was mapped as ‘Hardwood’ types historically, most is still that type today, with some being mapped as other types such as ‘Developed’.

title: Ecosystems and fire exposure of the central UP
text:
Goals
Using freely available LANDFIRE data, we take a look at the central Upper Peninsula of Michigan, plus some adjacent areas in Wisconsin to:

Quantify and compare the dominant ecosystems of the area, past and present
Explore how much ‘late-successional’ habitat would have been in the area past and present
Map out areas with the highest wildfire exposure risk, contextualized by historical fire regimes

We used the coding language R for data processing and visualization, plus 2 programs to make maps and process spatial data, ArcGIS Pro and QGIS. Learning more about LANDFIRE data and use of these tools was an additional goal.

title: Ecosystems and fire exposure of the central UP
text:
The Analysis Area
We aimed to delineate an analysis area that would both meet planning purposes of county officials in the central Upper Peninsula of Michigan (CUP) and be ecologically meaningful. To create the polygon by which we completed our analysis, we:

Selected the 6 central-most counties from the Census Bureau County Dataset (500m). Exported this data as a shapefile.
Used the ‘Select by Location’ tool with the U.S. HUC 8 Watershed Boundary from Data Basin and the 6 selected CUP counties as the ‘Selecting Features’. Data exported as a shapefile, projected to the NAD 1983 coordination system (WKID 4269).

This work was completed in ArcGIS Pro.
